div.p: In RPGs, most gameplay does not require rules. During play, players will generally refer to rules only in the following instances:

ul.li: The game world is alien enough that common sense cannot be used to resolve a situation. This is the case for magic spellcasting, for example.
Players and GMs have a common understanding that there is some nondeterministic influence - i.e., chance—in resolving a situation.
To resolve different understandings of a situation among different players or GMs, but participants can still agree on a probability value for certain outcomes.

div.p: Common rule systems create probabilities that are hard to gauge. In fact, only after playing a game for an extended period of time do patterns emerge. If the probabilities do not match expectations, they impact enjoyment.

The rules are written with these points in mind, which means: keep them comprehensible. This does not mean "generically simple," but rather that probabilities should not provide surprises when the subject matter changes.
The next section contains a few reasonable assumptions about rules and explains why our rules are chosen the way they are. If you are only interested in the mechanics, you can skip it.

Most rules are intended to resolve skill application, whether it be fighting, hiding, finding, lifting, or something else. A character can have different skill levels, but tasks at hand can also have different difficulty levels. We make the following assumptions.

ul.li: A skill proficiency and a task difficulty can be expressed as numbers. We define p as half of the probability for a skill of 0 to succeed at a task of level 1. This “half” is for technical reasons.

A skill level of k succeeds at a task of difficulty n+1 with the same probability as p times the probability that a skill of k succeeds at a task of difficulty n; i.e., you succeed at reducing the difficulty by one as a first step and then tackle the remaining portion.
A skill level of k succeeds at a task of difficulty 0 with the same probability as a skill level of 0 succeeds at a task of difficulty -k.

div.p: The numbers m, n, and k are your regular (non-negative integer) numbers. In the above setup, we will restrict ourselves to p=0.8. Note that the range of skill and task levels includes negative numbers. We treat a task level as a negative skill level; i.e., a (-k)-skill at a 0-task is the same as using a 0-skill at a k-task.
This is, in fact, all we need. The following are conclusions. This section was written solely to show that we make very few natural assumptions, which already imply the most important rule.

p.em: You roll a d5 until you roll a 1 and then count the number of dice that did not show a 1. That is the same as the number of dice you actually rolled minus one. This first number is used for the skill roll (of a character). We also call this the positive (stop) roll. The negative (stop) roll is associated with the task roll (the resistance of the environment or impediment), which is rolled/handled in the same way. The result of the negative stop roll (which is still a positive number) is subtracted from the result of the positive.

div.p: We elaborate by listing the probabilities involved as well as some examples. The mechanism is different from other RPG rules (I haven’t found any that use it), where you will often roll either a pool of dice and count those that meet a certain threshold or use a single die roll.

The following two tables are explanatory and not necessary. The mechanics have been described completely in the highlighted section. Everything else can be used to reduce the number of dice rolled or to better understand the implications of the (stop) roll mechanic.

In Table 1 the first row shows the results you can achieve when making a positive roll. Since you continue rolling until you get a 1 on your d5, you can interpret the complete positive stop roll as a series of d5 rolls as you move right on the first row, starting with 0. The second row shows the chance of moving up one point (i.e., right) at any given step as a percentage value. Note that this chance is always the same. The third row gives the chance of obtaining the result in the corresponding first row in each column. These are expressed as rolls on a d100. (This row can be used to reduce the number of rolls but still retain the benefits of the rule.) All but the first column of this row are approximations.

The last column is somewhat special. It combines all results beyond 9. Imagine you expand the table to infinity. While the extensions of the first and second rows are quite obvious, the third is not. It should be interpreted thus: if you roll 91-100, i.e., the highest 10%, you need to roll again on this table, get the result as before, and then add 10 to the result. (For the mathematically inclined, this is a recursive definition, since it is possible that you roll 91-100 again, which forces you to roll on this table again and add 20 to the net result from the repeated application. We will see this in the examples.) Some systems have a similar mechanic and call it an “exploding” roll or “open-ended”.

This table only considers one stop roll, either the positive or the negative. (You can also call them the skill and the task (stop) roll.) The next table shows the chances for overall results. The interpretation of the table is similar to the first.

Only the third row needs explanation. With a roll of 01-06 and 95-100 the extended roll continues on the previous table with corresponding consequences. Positive continuation - the one on the right end of the table with 95-100 - is exactly as before, while negative continuation results in negative values being added. For instance, rolling 02 and then a 25 gives a result of -11. The second row cell below the 0 result means a 4/9 (44%) chance to increase the result by 1, the same chance to decrease the result by 1, and a 1/9 (11%) chance to stay at 0. The astute reader will see the chance for 0 in the third row is only 8%, while 1/9 is approximately 11%. This “error” is due to rounding - the price for rolling fewer dice.

A stop roll is rolling a d5 until a 1 is rolled. Physical dice cannot have five equal faces, so you can use a d10 that stops on 1 and 2 instead. To improve speed, several d10s may be rolled in an ordered fashion. Order them according to size or alphabetical color (e.g., black, blue, green, yellow) or in any other way you can remember. If you lack d10s, you can also roll d6s with only a marginal 3% error on each roll, or you can reroll all 6s. But all players (and the GM) should roll the same way. Computer applications that make rolling as easy as pressing a button are also easy to program.

Assume you decided to use the third row in Table 1 with a d100 and rolled a 24 on the first roll. This means a result of 1 on the first table. The second roll (the negative or passive roll) shows a 50, which results in 3 for a net result of -2.
Using Table 2, a 28 is rolled, which results in -3.

A more exotic roll would be the sequence 96, 99, 93, 61 on the d100. The result would be 34 for a positive stop roll. For a combined stop roll, the result would be 29 (and the roll of 61 ignored, because it is not needed, since the 93 already “stops” on Table 2).

Using the d10-for-d5 replacement method, the positive sequence on a d10 shows 3, 8, 10, 7, 9, 4, 6, 3, 10, 10, 8, 4, 2 and the negative sequence shows 3, 6, 9, 4, 4, 1. The result is positive 12 and negative 5 with a net result of +7.

Skill and task rolls are symmetrical. If you imagine one character stealthily evading another, the first may interpret the rolls as his skill at evading observation, while the second may interpret the rolls as his skill in successfully observing the vicinity. Either way, one roll (or set of rolls) will determine the outcome.

When describing a situation, the actor and the obstacle both possess a certain level. The first is usually a skill in the particular act and the second a measure of the difficulty of the task. In the previous example, the observer might have a (skill) level of 5 and finding the clandestine character a (task) level of 3. These levels will be added to the positive and negative stop rolls, respectively.

We are adding and subtracting four numbers: stop rolls and levels. The calculations result in a level difference between the positive and negative part (or the skill level and task level), which is relevant for rolling. If only the failure or success is of interest and not the degree of success or failure, you can apply the following shortcut. Since the level difference must be met by the lower-level contestant, you may roll all the difference dice in one combined attempt and check whether any stop digit appears. If it does, the lower contestant cannot win, since it is irrelevant where the stop digit appears. If the stop digit does not appear, chances are reduced to 50/50, and you can flip a coin in any of a number of ways.

For example, suppose a climber with a skill level of 57 wants to scale a cliff of difficulty level 49. The difference is 8. The GM rolls 8 dice, which show 3, 5, 6, 1, 3, 9, 9, and 8. Since 1 is a stop digit, the cliff is scaled. (The cliff has the lower level!) Suppose the 1 had been a 7 instead - the cliff would have had a good chance to drop the character. The GM decides that even is good for the character and odd is bad, and rolls a d10. It comes up a 6, and thus the character has barely made it.

Another pragmatic rule applies to differences of at least 10. Rolling 10 non-stop rolls in a row to match a level difference of 10 can be shortened to rolling a 1 on a d10. (The chance, 1/10, is an approximation of the exact chance.) In fact, the choice of 80% (d5) in the initial paragraph was made for the reason that this heuristic holds.
Also known as light rules, the above easily scales into a lighter version. Divide the skill values above by 10 and record them as such. This will give a 90% advantage to someone with one more point.

As an example, we record a skill called Fisticuff with a 1-5 star rating. When you have two opponents, either simply declare the one with more stars the winner, or roll a d10, and he wins with 1 through 9. With equal rating, or with a 10 on the d10, you have a draw - if that is an acceptable outcome. If not, flip a coin to see who the winner is.

The following rules address common situations. How do you combine a group of actors that support each other? How do you apply two different skills to a task that involves both? You should never indiscriminately add skill values. Remember that a difference of 10 means a 90% winning difference by design.
Taking the best skill roll of two (this is the same as requiring at least one of the two to succeed) can be done by using the table below.

Suppose you want to combine the skills n and m of two actors, where the respective task difficulties have already been subtracted. In the first row, you index the positive difference between n and m. The second row will then give you the bonus to add to the higher of the two skills - which is then the only one you need to roll. For example, if the skills are 5 and 9. Then the net skill level of the two actors together is 12.

If you use the rule multiple times, always group two actors of similar skill levels together to reduce rounding errors. (This is normalized skill level, i.e., the task level has already been subtracted.) The application of this rule should not depend on the order or sub-grouping of several actors, but rounding errors are present in the table. See below to avoid them.

As a more elaborate example, say you have four characters in a room searching for something and you have determined that this technically means that any of those characters could find it, i.e., all would have to roll against a set difficulty. But you want just one roll; imagine you had a group search skill. These characters have skill levels of 5, 7, 13, and 17. Taking the first two, because they are closest to each other, we combine them into an actor with 11. Now we combine 11 and 13 in the same manner to 17. In the last step, we combine 17 and 17 into 22.

If you have two actors that both must succeed at a test, that is equivalent to using the inverse stop roll, which means exchanging the role of positive and negative for the purposes of combining. Logically, this means that either of the two obstacles (formerly known as actors) may foil the actor (originally the obstacle). Keep in mind that the reversal of positive and negative roll also changes who of the two has the higher skill level. This may require a bit of getting used to.

Imagine in the previous example that the same characters are trying to hide from a guard. If either one is detected, the guard will raise the alarm and the maneuver fails. As luck would have it, their Hide skill level is exactly their Search skill level. But in the inverse, the guard is active and he has to succeed at detecting any of the four. Task (inverse skill) levels 5 and 7 will turn into 1. Then 13 and 17 (closest together) will turn into 10. The combined level of the task (inverse skill) groups 1 and 10 turns into -1. Since the guard isn’t really paying attention, the GM gives the guard a skill level of 0. That still leaves the group with a 60% failure chance.

If you are worried about rounding errors, particularly when adding large numbers of skills or tasks, use the following formula, where β is the difference in level you plug in and the addition to the higher value is calculated. Round only when done with the 5-addition - as late as possible. (I advise you to use this formula only if you are a rule designer who needs to deal with scaling issues.) Reserve this for situations where players attempt to “break the rules” by exploiting the rounding errors.

A skill may be broken down into related skills, if so desired. The decomposition must be such that the combination of the (weighted) averages of the new skill levels results in the original skill level. Additional measures should be in place to indicate that the skills actually belong to a group. (A typical restriction is that the individual skills of a group may not differ by more than 10 points.)

If a decomposition results in multiple rolls, make sure that the rules of Combinations remain valid. A typical example would be to turn a roll that would usually apply every 10 days into a roll that applies every day. This implies that each of the daily rolls has its difficulty increased by 10.

Breaking down and then recombining skills is a useful tool to extend the skill space beyond what rules generally cover. Imagine that a PC wants to tie a knot, but his skill sheet says he has skill level 5 as a Sailor and level 3 as a Mountaineer. For tasks like knots where the difficulty is the same for a Sailor and a Mountaineer, the GM can allow the PC to use a 9. The reasoning is that the knot skill application works as if two separate skills (actors) were trying to tie the knot in combination. Be careful, however, with allowing such additions, because if you treat 0 as the value an untrained individual has, then in the above case a sailor who has never seen a mountain would still have a 0 in mountaineering, and adding a 0 would yield an effective knot skill of 8.

We suggest normalizing skills and tasks to zero (0). What does that mean? This value should represent the skill level of an untrained, uneducated, but otherwise healthy 20-year-old human. This is a fictional person. For instance, in order to compare different language skills, we assume this normal person has none. When it comes to gender or racial differences, we also suggest creating a fictitious average.

A skill may be applied in multiple dimensions. It may be used to evaluate something, to produce something, to use something, and more within the appropriate domain. It can happen under time pressure or at one’s leisure. These different variable results are called dimensions. A typical dimension is the time it takes to apply a skill. Another typical dimension is the quality of the result. It is useful to prepare common dimensions for skill application, both to be prepared and to remain consistent over time.

If an actor decides to use multiple dimensions at the same time, this is called a trajectory. For example, assume that we have two common applications of a skill called Fletching: creating an arrow of standard quality, where time varies, and creating an arrow while whittling for an hour, where quality varies. In preparing for an upcoming attack on his village, the character wants to create good arrows quickly. The GM rules that this results in 50% speed and 50% quality. This is a typical trajectory.

Judging the value of goods produced or performances delivered works the same for almost all skills, which is why this dimension fits into the general framework. Since the spread of these values in the concrete environment remains unknown, let us look at how these values are derived and how they are interpreted.

Consider that you want to express a certainty between 100% and 0%. In an example scenario, you might rule that someone with a skill level of 20 is 80% certain, and that someone with a 0 has 0% certainty. The rest is interpolated and extrapolated accordingly, e.g., at 10 the certainty is 40%. If you do not want to have the spread as an independent dimension, you can calculate this as between
V x C and V / C
where C represents the certainty value between 0 and 1 (the percentage divided by 100) and V the actual value known only to the GM.

Write down the results of these calculations according to the skills you are interested in. (You can see an example of this in Harnmaster.) Now assume that you have determined both C and V for a specific instance. Since these numbers are usually not easy to work with, choose any number by any arbitrary means between (roughly) the values given in the above formula. This is the estimate that the PC is given. If he is interested in how accurate he is - for instance, to check whether a merchant is trying to outsmart him in a trade - he can do the reverse operation and be sure that the true value is within that range.

As a concrete example, suppose you determine C = 0.60 (60%) and V is $160. We are picking these numbers to show that the calculations are not difficult even if the numbers appear to be so. Now eyeball C roughly as two thirds. Multiplying $160 by 2/3 gives roughly $100, and dividing by it (multiplying by 3/2) gives roughly $250, thus an interval between $100 and $250. If these calculations still seem excessive, consider any other method of approximation. Now pick a random value in that range, e.g., roll a d100 and say low is at the lower end. That number comes up 87 in our example, so we tell the PC his estimate is $200. The PC wants to buy that item, so he wants to gauge the value more accurately in order not to be ripped off but also not to miss out on a good deal. Being a number cruncher, he will do the reverse operation with rigor. Because he knows his certainty to be 60%, he calculates the interval:

This interval contains the real value $160 and leaves the PC a little wiser, but he is not in a very good bargaining position. Note that for large values of C (close to 1) you can use V/C = V x (2 - C) if you’d rather use multiplication instead of division.
In summary: use certainty in any way you agree with your playing group. The above provides a way to express uncertainty less ambiguously.

This is a very simple dimension often used intuitively. When a result roll is positive (e.g., +3) then the normal success is exceeded by the same amount as a constant percentage (e.g., 10%, which would mean 30% overachievement). To obtain a sensible constant, it is useful to think of the result roll that would yield 0%.

Say that -20 would mean disaster and nothing is achieved at all. This implies that from 0% to 100% we have 20 points to bridge, which puts each point at 5%, which is the constant percentage. We get (as an example):

An exponential scale is not as easy to compute. Unfortunately, it is more natural to our ruleset. It can be simplified by using tables where necessary. The reason this is more natural is the way differences in the value behave: 10 more points mean 10 times as likely to succeed; this is the defining property of an exponential curve.
A very simple dimension is this: when you say that 4 people are as likely to succeed as a single person who has 10 more points. In that case, you can also use 5-addition.

As a concrete simple example, assume that a person who is 10 times as skilled as another produces four times the result of the lesser. That would be equivalent to simply adding the results of the aforementioned 4 lesser people. Maybe think of adding the weights each individual can lift so that in total they simply add up. That is row Result 4 in the next table.

Another result would be that 4 people cannot simultaneously address the problem with the same efficiency. They would stand in each other’s way, reserve tools exclusively, etc. In row Result 2 we assume that these 4 people are only twice as effective as one person. Since there is some rounding taking place, the number in parentheses gives a factor that is often easier to work with than the more exact percentage.

Note that you could simply multiply the d20 skill levels by two or take half for the percentile system - why use a strange mapping? Since we do not intend to simulate other rules in this manner, you can certainly do that conversion. We provide the details to show that these rules do not have the natural chance progression we desire. But a simple mapping is also included.

Many rulesets rank a skill on a percentile scale, 0% through 100%. This is the case for Rolemaster, RuneQuest, or Harnmaster. Rolling below your skill value means you succeed (or formulated equivalently). The skill levels (in our rules) are 0, 10, 20, and 30, and they can be mapped to the classical skill values of 5%, 35%, 65%, and 95%. That means these rules have about forty skill levels, into which all values fall according to our system. To keep things simple, use:
skill level = 4/10 x classic value

Something similar is true for Dungeons & Dragons, Pathfinder, or generally the d20 family of rules, which use twenty 5% steps instead of the finer-grained 1% steps. Our levels 0, 10, ..., 40 correspond to the classic skill bonuses of +0, +9, +18, +27, and +36. These steps are approximations, since none of these rolls are translation-invariant. To keep things simple, use:
skill level = classic bonus

The one-page character sheet is applicable to all rules. You need to fill in the relevant skills and tasks for a character. Since the possible combinations are virtually limitless, list only the most common ones or add another sheet if you do not find a suitable decomposition of skills and tasks.
